What are “killer bees”? 
» 
The name the American media gave to an aggressive type of 
honeybees found in the Americas starting in the late 1950s 
» 
So named because of the highly defensive behavior of this 
type of bee, and stinging incidents 
1000 people killed due to overwhelming stinging attacks 
“Famous” 
attack in 1986 (Costa Rica): Inn Siang 
Ooi 
died from 8000 stings (7 stings/ sq. cm) during an OTS 
field trip. 
» 
It is, in fact, a hybrid honey bee derived from crosses between 
European and eastern African honey bee subspecies 
» 
A more appropriate name is Africanized honeybees or AHB

o
 
Warwick Kerr 
introduced 
54 honey 
bee queens from 
Tanzania and South 
Africa into Brazil for 
testing in 1956. 
o
 
Intent was to combine 
tameness and honey 
production of 
European bees with 
African traits ideal for 
hot/tropical climates

•
Tasked with geneticist from Brazil who was tasked by his government to initiate a program to 
improve the ability of the Brazilian honeybees to make honey.
•
Brazilian honey bees were like ligustica who were not really adapted to Brazilian environment. 
Looked for ways to have more tropical bees
—> imported honeybees from scutellata and a bit more south
•
wanted to hybridize scutellata with ligustica, hoping he would get a progeny that would be as tame as 
the European, but as adapted to a tropical environment as the scutellata
•
scutellata was more resistant to diseases and also has a greater reproductive rate
•
had an expiremental station with hives that had African queens that had been imported from from 
Eastern Africa
•
in order to prevent the the queens from escaping, he placed a queen excluder, a mesh that allows the 
worker bee to go through, but the Queen's cannot because their thorax is actually thicker. 
•
Somebody removed the excluders and African queens escaped with some the progeny 
•
Started feral population and spread through most of Central America, South America, and even 
reached North America
•
From original location 1957 Rio Claro, Brazil —> Peru 1982 —> Colombia 1979 —> Nicaragua 
1982—>Mexico 1982 —> USA 1990s

What it is like working with killer bees: 
“Merely walking toward the colonies elicited a massive 
response on the part of the bees, so that the situation 
was out of control before we smoked and opened our 
first colony. Bees were everywhere, banging into our 
veils and helmets with such ferocity that we could barely 
hear each other and stinging through our layered 
clothing. It was a hot, humid day, and the combination of 
sweat, noise, and stings forced us to retreat after 
examining only a few colonies. The bees followed us all 
the way back to the car, and we had to keep our 
equipment on until we were far out of their stinging 
range.... On this occasion I received over 
fifty stings 
in 
just a few minutes, in spite of my heavy beekeeping 
armor, and I could only imagine what a full day of 
working with these bees would be like.” 
From: M.L. Winston, Killer Bees (1984)
